l.emph: Smiling the cheerful face of spring is seen

lg.l: Come, Corydon,33 Pastoral shepherd, generally characterized as ineffectual in love, first appearing in Theocritus, Idylls 4 and 5. Corydon subsequently appears in, among others, Virgil’s Eclogue 2; Juvenal 9.102; Petrarch, Eclogue 6.144; Sidney, Arcadia (1593); and Milton, L’Allegro 83. For a comprehensive list see Alastair Fowler, Literary Names (Oxford: Oxford UP, 2012), p. 48 n.16. let us our walk pursue,
The winding banks and shady woods among,
Where little birds their madrigals renew,
Come, Corydon, and listen to their song.
How sweet the linnet warbles from the spray,
The blackbird echoes through the vocal grove;
The mavis modulates her tuneful lay,
The painted goldfinch and the cooing dove.
And hark, the cuckoo, harbinger of spring,
Though least melodious of the tuneful quire;
Yet, most sweet bird, I joy to hear thee sing,
Thou welcome poet of the vernal lyre.
Say, Corydon, would’st thou this bliss forego?

Would’st thou forsake fair Irvine’s shady bow’rs?44 Located in North Ayrshire on the banks of the eponymously-named River, the coastal town of Irvine, where Burns lived briefly to learn flax-dressing. The river after which it is named flows through southwest Scotland, running near Kilmarnock. Turnbull devoted two other poems to Irvine in Poetical Essays, “Irvine Water,” and “Ode VIII: To Irvine Water.”
For all the wealth that pop’lous cities show,
For all the pride of great Edina’s55 Edinburgh. tow’rs?
Rich landscapes, from Italian masters bought,
Delight the great, and gayly deck the wall,
And here the little sylvan songsters caught,
To make the house an epitome of all.
Let these the world, in miniature, possess,
And rob the feather’d race of liberty,
I’ll have the whole, nor be content with less,
And nature form a landscape fit for me.
